occurrences.line_text: Therewith an hollow, dreary, murmuring voyce
She dolefull Lady, like a dreary Spright,
And staunch the bleeding of her dreary wound.
And at the last through dreary dolour die:
And in his armes the dreary dying mayd,
Hath thee opprest, and with sad drearyhead
The which to heare, vouchsafe, O dearest dred a-while.
Which therein shrouded from the tempest dred,
And forth he cald out of deepe darknesse dred
Nor dred of Romanes, then was Aruirage,
To shunne Rocke of Reproch, and it as death to dred.
Whiles the dred daunger does behind remaine.
Hereto perforce. But ï¿½ dred Soueraine
Made them recoile, and fly from dred decay,
Euer alike, as if her former dred
Her selfe not saued yet from daunger dred
With shoure and hayle so horrible and dred,
Empoisned was with priuy lust, and gealous dred.
Do thou dred infant, Venus dearling doue,
With darknes dred, and threatens all the world to wast.
Ne any but your selfe, O dearest dred,
And to all people did diuide her dred beheasts.
Nought could he do, but shun the dred despight
Which she against the dred Mercilla oft did frame.
He that whylome in Spaine so sore was dred,
Without suspect of ill or daungers hidden dred.
Echidna is a Monster direfull dred,
The Lady, for that she was much in dred,
But darkenesse dred and daily night did houer
For with dredd Maiestie, and awfull ire,
And darkenesse dredd, that neuer viewed day,
And battell made the dreddest daungerous,
That day, the dreddest day that liuing wight
But he sad man, when he had long in drede
Whereat her heart was fild with hope and drede;
Would not for ought be drawne to former drede,
And yet more sad, that Vna his deare dreed
The ground eke groned vnder him for dreed;
And cast to seeke him forth through daunger and great dreed.
To hide his coward head from dying dreed.
He flong it from him, and deuoyd of dreed,
By that same wicked witch, to worke vs dreed,
To doe away vaine doubt, and needlesse dreed:
With no lesse haste, and eke with no lesse dreed,
She was astonisht with exceeding dreed,
Vpon the ground, withouten doubt or dreed,
Quites Mirabell from dreed:
Seeking to driue away deepe rooted dreede,
That he awoke out of his idle dreme,
That none him durst awake out of his dreme;
As men awaked rashly out of dreme,
Out of the well, wherein he drenched lay;
Where drenched deepe he found in that dull ford
That drenched lay full deepe, vnder the Garden side.
Deepe was he drenched to the vpmost chin,
Had drenched them, he drowned him againe;
He drenched was, she at the length dispacht him,
In daunger rather to be drent, then brent?
Another wretch, whose carkasse deepe was drent
May backe returne, but is condemned to be drent.
To see her Lord, that was reported drent,
A ruefull spectacle of death and ghastly drere.
The hoars Night-rauen, trump of dolefull drere,
That with their drerie wounds and bloudy gore
Lanc't through the arme, fell down with him in drerie swound.
That it importunes death and dolefull drerihed.
Through suddein feare and ghastly drerihed,
With ghastly lookes and dreadfull drerihed;
Full of sad feare and ghastly dreriment,
Enrold in flames, and smouldring dreriment,
Her daintie limbs in her sad dreriment,
And scratcht her face with ghastly dreriment,
She fled away with ghastly dreriment,
And shaking off his drowzie dreriment,
And couer'd heauen with hideous dreriment,
And gamesom merth to grieuous dreriment:
Foule horror, and eke hellish dreriment:
But fled away with ghastly dreriment,
And Braggadochio selfe with dreriment
But for to tell the dolefull dreriment,
His foltring toung with pangs of drerinesse,
Where nought but darkesome drerinesse she found,
Who when returning from the drery Night,
On which the drery death did sit, as sad
Fit to adorne the dead, and decke the drery toombe.
Thereto as cold and drery as a Snake,
In drery darkenesse, and continuall feare
Which drery sight the gentle Squire espying,
But when Briana saw that drery stound,
He also gan vplooke with drery eye,
And stouping downe to her in drery swound,
That hath me driuen to this drery stound.
He gan to comfort, and his wounds to dresse.
Defowled, and their Lady dresse his wownd,
She gathered vp and did about him dresse,
And her welpointed weapons did about her dresse.
For herbes to dresse their wounds; still seeming faine,
Dayly she dressed him, and did the best
And all the while his wounds were dressing, by him stayd.
A daintie damzell, dressing of her heare,
With sprincled pearle, and gold full richly drest,
For thousand times he so himselfe had drest,
And shoke his scales to battell readie drest;
No arboret with painted blossomes drest,
Faire Lady she him seemd, like Lady drest,
Hast drest my sinfull wounds? I kisse thy blessed feete.
His ready wound with better salues new drest;
Then like a Faerie knight himselfe he drest;
Had knowne right well with colourd ribbands drest:
For ill your goddesse seruices are drest
Such were these Hags, and so vnhandsome drest:
Their ranckling wounds, & euery day them duely drest.
That sore her payn'd, by any to be drest,
Into their comely tresses dewly drest,
Through that false witch, and that foule aged dreuill,
But to the pray when as he drew more ny,
When nigh he drew vnto this gentle payre
When as this knight nigh to the Ladie drew,
Nigh as he drew, they might perceiue his head
That drew on men Gods hatred, and his wrath,
By this the dreadfull Beast drew nigh to hand,
She nigher drew, and saw that ioyous end:
And drew her on the ground, and his sharpe sword,
The dead knights sword out of his sheath he drew,
Drew them in parts, and each made others foe;
Whereto he drew in haste it to agree.
Drew by the haire along vpon the ground,
And drew his deadly weapon, to maintain his part.
With that he drew his flaming sword, and strooke
That thee against me drew with so impetuous dread.
Drew him through durt and myre without remorse,
Guyon obayd; So him away he drew
Who soone prepard to field, his sword forth drew,
Atin drew nigh, to weet what it mote bee;
Firme is thy faith, whom daunger neuer fro me drew.
Which to auenge, the Palmer him forth drew
Arraught the rule, and from their father drew,
And taking armes, the Britons to her drew;
Still as the greedy knight nigh to him drew,
Whom such when Guyon saw, he drew him neare,
The noble Elfe, and carefull Palmer drew
Drew out a deadly bow and arrow keene,
Drew the smooth charet of sad Cymoent;
And euer as he nigher to her drew,
Then drew he his bright sword, & gan about him throw.
But, as he nigher drew, he easily
With that out of his bouget forth he drew
There they dismounting, drew their weapons bold
But drew her selfe aside in sickernesse,
A murdrous knife out of his pocket drew,
And fiercely forth her mortall blade she drew,
Now freely drew, and found right safe assurance theare.
By that the louely paire drew nigh to hond:
And thrise he drew it backe: so did at last forbeare.
Drew nigh, to weete the cause of their debate:
The which eftsoones discouered, to it drew
And when his speare was brust, his sword he drew,
Full glad of so good end, to them drew nere,
And drew thereto, making her eare her guide.
He to it drew, to weet who there did wonne;
By chance he certaine miniments forth drew,
Till she drew neare, and then againe remoue;
She drew her far, and led with slow delay.
Eftsoones that pretious liquour forth he drew,
To which they drew, ere night vpon them fell;
Soft rombling brookes, that gentle slomber drew;
Who playing on his harpe, vnto him drew
With that his sword he drew all wrathfully,
Eftsoones his Page drew to the Castle gate,
Vnder an heape of gold. Thence he her drew
Till that at length nigh to the sea they drew;
In sdeignfull wize he drew vnto him neare,
With th'other drew his sword: for with the same
He nigh them drew to stay th'auengers forse,
That glauncing downe his thigh, the purple bloud forth drew.
But drew him on with hope, fit leasure to awayt.
Who as she nigh vnto them drew, the one
Which she accepting, he so neare her drew,
They drew their swords, in mind to make amends
And touched with intire affection, nigh him drew.
If he too rashly to his charet drew,
Oft drew the Prince vnto his charret nigh,
At last from his victorious shield he drew
As when the firie-mouthed steeds, which drew
But Talus soone him ouertooke, and backward drew.
But as he nigher drew, three knights he spyde,
They drew vnto his aide; but that rude rout
But when as nigh vnto the shore they drew,
So sounded the retraite, and drew his folke away.
That he therewith the knight drew all about:
And for their better comfort to them nigher drew.
Drew to the gate, and there with prayers meeke,
Wherefore he stayd, till that he nearer drew,
That from his steed him nigh he drew againe.
He to her drew, and with faire blandishment
Who through thicke woods and brakes & briers him drew,
Whereof exceeding glad, he to him drew,
Yet sau'd not so, but that the bloud it drew,
And to the dore of death for sorrow drew,
So forth he drew much gold, and toward him it driue.
He nigher drew, to weete what mote it be;
Drew neare, that he the truth of all by him mote learne.
Him hardly forward drew, whereas the thiefe
Tho when as towards darksome night it drew,
Yet left not quite, but drew a litle space
With which he drew him forth, euen in his own despight.
Th'one faire and fresh, the other old and dride:
That the drie withered stocke it gan refresh,
Doth burne the earth, and boyled riuers drie,
First from one coast, till nought thereof be drie;
And soild with dust of the long dried way;
Her dried dugs, like bladders lacking wind,
As withered leaues drop from their dried stockes,
The driest wood is soonest burnt to dust.
Th'end of his drift, he praisd his diuelish arts,
Doth roll adowne the rocks, and fall with fearefull drift.
He seekes, of all his drift the aymed end:
At last them driuen hath to this despairefull drift.
Else she will slip away, and all our drift despise.
His secret drift, till he her layd abord.
Whose hidden drift he could not well perceiue;
The wicked driftes of trayterous desynes,
Nepenthe is a drinck of souerayne grace,
Are by the Gods to drinck thereof assynd;
But such as drinck, eternall happinesse do fynd.
Till comming to this well, he stoupt to drincke:
To drincke hereof, whereby all cares forepast
Whose mind in meat and drinke was drowned so,
And thristy giue to drinke, a worke of grace:
At last when lust of meat and drinke was ceast,
Of deadly drugs I gaue him drinke anon,
Yet gaped still, as coueting to drinke
Of grace I pray thee, giue to eat and drinke to mee.
Thereof she vsd to giue to drinke to each,
That she may sucke their life, and drinke their blood,
Her golden cup to them for drinke she raught,
Ne other drinke there did he euer tast,
That I mote drinke the cup, whereof she dranke:
Ne drinke of wine, for wine they say is blood,
Be gotten, not begotten, which should drinke
Offred him drinke, to quench his thirstie heat,
And drinke of euery brooke, when thirst my throte doth boyle.
Then when with meates and drinkes of euery kinde
Of meates and drinkes their appetites suffiz'd,
Now when of meats and drinks they had their fill,
To driue away the dull melancholy,
And each to deadly shame would driue his foe:
By that same way the direfull dames doe driue
None else to death this man despayring driue,
To driue him to despaire, and quite to quaile,
The streame thereof would driue a water-mill.
To driue away the dull Melancholy;
So parted we and on our iourney driue,
And driue me to withdraw my blind abused loue.
Nor timely tides did driue out of their sluggish sourse.
Did driue the Romanes to the weaker side,
Yet thee fierce Fortune did so nearely driue,
To strike his oares, and mightily doth driue
And after them did driue with all her power and might.
Or wrathfull Neptune did them driue before
Into the Ocean deepe to driue their weary droue.
That so deepe wound through these deare members driue.
So from the wearie spirit thou doest driue
In their sterne brests, on him which late did driue
And saw his drouer driue along the streame,
Of th'inland folke, which sought him backe to driue,
And lacke of reskewes will to parley driue;
And with fowle force vnto his will did driue,
And of the dreadfull discord, which did driue
Them reconcyld againe, and to their homes did driue.
He can let driue at him with all his power,
That seem'd to dust he shortly would it driue:
The heauens abhorre, and into darkenesse driue.
With dreadfull strokes let driue at him so sore,
But suffred that same Dwarfe me to her dongeon driue.
So dreadfull strokes each did at other driue,
Against those two let driue, as they were wood:
And either beat him in, or driue him out.
Her from the quarrey he away doth driue,
They seeing that, let driue at him streight way,
Let driue at her with all her dreadfull might,
They slay the Soudan, driue his wife
Gan driue at him, with so huge might and maine,
Seeking to driue away deepe rooted dreede,
The whilest at him so dreadfully he driue,
And can let driue at him so dreadfullie,
What new ocasion doth thee hither driue,
He gan at him let driue more fiercely then afore.
He greater grew, and gan to driue at him more hard.
Shall driue a Mill, within strong bancks is pent,
To driue you so on foot vnfit to tread,
So did that Squire his foes disperse, and driue asonder.
Let driue at him with so malitious mynd,
Let driue at him so dreadfully amaine,
Them selues to any trade, as for to driue
To helpe faire Pastorella, home to driue
And through ambition downe themselues doe driue
So forth he drew much gold, and toward him it driue.
Watching to driue the rauenous Wolfe away,
Deuiz'd all goodly meanes, from her to driue
Ne her out of the stedfast sadle driued,
So deepely dinted in the driuen clay,
Some others were new driuen, and distent
Into this land by chaunce haue driuen bene,
Driuen by fatall error, here arriu'd,
At last them driuen hath to this despairefull drift.
Driuen to great distresse by Fortune straunge,
At last by fatall course they driuen were
A silly Pilgrim driuen to distresse,
Fast locked, driuen with that stormy blast,
Forcibly driuen with contrarie tydes
That oft I driuen am to great distresse,
That hath me driuen to this drery stound.
He driuen was to ground in selfe despight;
But with his dreadfull hornes them driues afore,
And with his staffe, that driues his Heard astray,
Driues backe the current of his kindly course,
With that he driues at them with dreadfull might,
Like as a ship, whom cruell tempest driues
Along the fomy waues driuing his finny droue.
Towards them driuing like a storme out sent.
And to him driuing strongly downe the tide,
And drizling teares did shed for pure affection.
His watry eyes, drizling like deawy raine,
Ryding vpon a Dromedare on hie,
At last when droncke with drowsinesse, he woke,
His dronken corse he scarse vpholden can,
Doth license him depart at sound of morning droome.
That molten starres do drop like weeping eyes;
Nor drop of bloud in all his face appeares
Her feeble pulse, to proue if any drop
With one sweet drop of sensuall delight:
As withered leaues drop from their dried stockes,
Ne drop of bloud appeared shed to bee,
And if that any drop of slombring rest
And from their fruitfull sides sweet gum did drop,
Yet from the wound no drop of bloud there fell,
One drop of bloud to fall, but did restore
His dewy lockes did drop with brine apace,
And they with aire, that not a drop can slide:
Christalline humour dropped downe apace.
Dropped adowne vpon her yuorie brest:
Dropped with brackish deaw; his three-forkt Pyke
His subtill tongue, like dropping honny, mealt'th
Sweet words, like dropping honny she did shed,
Others sweet words, dropping like honny dew;
Dreadfully dropping from her dying hart,
Yet dropping fresh in hand did her detect,
Yet dropping fresh out of the Indian fount,
The bloudie gore and poyson dropping lothsomely.
Small drops of gory bloud, that trickled downe the same.
Wherein were closd few drops of liquor pure,
That drops of bloud thence like a well did play;
And with dry drops congealed in her eye,
The flood of drops, the Monster filth did breede:
But sparks, seed, drops, and filth do thus delay;
The drops dry vp, and filth wipe cleane away:
Which drops of Christall seemd for wantones to weepe.
Few drops, more cleare then Nectar, forth distild,
That drops of purple bloud thereout did weepe,
And many drops of milke and bloud through it did spill.
While teares stood in his eies, few drops of bitternesse.
That little drops empurpled her faire brest.
In sted thereof with drops of melting loue,
Deawed with siluer drops, through sweating sore;
And with few drops thereof did softly dew
Dew'd with her drops of bountie Soueraine,
Deawed with siluer drops, that trickled downe alway.
Congealed litle drops, which doe the morne adore.
Few perling drops from her faire lampes of light;
And hung the head, soone as few drops of raine
And a dry dropsie through his flesh did flow:
Some scumd the drosse, that from the metall came;
When darknesse he in deepest dongeon droue,
That to the earth him droue, as stricken dead,
The which him into great amaz'ment droue,
And droue them to recoile: but when againe
But Guyon droue so furious and fell,
Into the Ocean deepe to driue their weary droue.
And droue at him with all his might and maine
And with the tide droue forward careleslie;
Along the fomy waues driuing his finny droue.
They rudely droue to ground both man and horse,
Againe he droue at him with double might,
The shield it droue, and did the couering reare:
Who yesterday droue vs to such distresse,
Into the sea he droue quite from that soyle,
My knight hers soone, as seemes, to daunger droue
And droue away the stound, which mortally attacht him.
The selfe same euening fortune hether droue,
And droue away their flocks, with other much disorder.
So droue them all away, and his loue with him bore.
And saw his drouer driue along the streame,
That with vntimely drought nigh withered was,
Calling thy helpe in vaine, that here in ioyes art dround.
Of his wide Labyrinth, and then to haue them dround.
And the fraile soule in deepe delight nigh dround:
And down the rock him throwing, in the sea him dround.
To these sicke twaine, that now began to droupe,
The drouping Night thus creepeth on them fast,
By this the drouping day-light gan to fade
His daughter gan despise his drouping day,
Till drouping Phoebus gan to hide his golden hed.
So as they trauelled, the drouping night
With drearie drouping eyne lookt vp like one aghast.
The whiles he steru'd with hunger and with drouth
Bad doe away the dampe of drouzie sleepe,
Where when all drownd in deadly sleepe he findes,
Perceiu'd my thought, and drownd in sleepie night,
Still drownd in sleepe, and most of his dayes ded;
For all her words she drownd with laughter vaine,
His horses backe, for dread of being drownd,
And drowne in dissolute delights apart,
Readie to drowne himselfe for fell despight.
And stroue in vaine, the one himselfe to drowne,
His lustlesse limbes, and drowne his baser mind,
For in the sea to drowne her selfe she fond,
Shall drowne all Holland with his excrement,
Thereto approch, ne filth mote therein drowne:
And vnto Morpheus comes, whom drowned deepe
Whiles you in carelesse sleepe are drowned quight.
And all in deadly sleepe did drowned lie,
Whose mind in meat and drinke was drowned so,
That drowned all the land, whereon he stood;
And all his senses drowned in deepe senselesse waue.
Was drowned in the depth of deadly sleepe,
Full deepe emplonged was, and drowned nye,
Slew cruelly, and in the riuer drowned quight.
Had drenched them, he drowned him againe;
And there her drowned in the durty mud:
I rew that thus thy better dayes are drowned
Of sencelesse sleepe did deeply drowned lie,
Now drowned in the depth of sleepe all fearelesse lay.
For all his dayes he drownes in priuitie,
Him slaies, drownes Lady Munera
And either both them drownes, or trayterously slaies.
From drowning. But more happie he, then wise
The other both from drowning for to saue,
Vp to the skyes, that them of drowning made affeard.
In drowsie fit he findes: of nothing he takes keepe.
The day is spent, and commeth drowsie night,
Vprose from drowsie couch, and him addrest
Approch, albe his drowsie den were next;
Like as a Lyon, that in drowsie caue
At last when droncke with drowsinesse, he woke,
The royall virgin shooke off drowsy-hed,
And shaking off his drowzie dreriment,
The drowzie humour of the dampish night,
Purged from drugs of foule intemperance:
Of deadly drugs I gaue him drinke anon,
Made drunke with drugs of deare voluptuous receipt.
The which Rinaldo drunck in happie howre,
Or that the charme and venim, which they druncke,
That fed on liuing flesh, & druncke mens vitall blood.
Whereof full glad for thirst, ech drunk an harty draught.
Of such as drunke her life, the which them nurst;
Drunke vp his life; his corse left on the strand.
That drunke with bloud, yet thristed after life:
And all that drunke thereof, did faint and feeble grow.
Drunke of the streame, as cleare as cristall glas;
Made drunke with drugs of deare voluptuous receipt.
And drunke with bloud of men, slaine by his might,
Into the riuer, where he drunke his deadly last.
Wherewith she makes her louers drunken mad,
The drunken lampe downe in the oyle did steepe,
And there the relicks of the drunken fray,
So many Centaures drunken soules to hell,
To weet, sterne Druon, and lewd Claribell,
And Paridell and Druon fiercely laid
Druons delight was all in single life,
For Paridell did take to Druons side,
The vine-prop Elme, the Poplar neuer dry,
And scorching Sunne does dry my secret vaines:
And a dry dropsie through his flesh did flow:
And with dry drops congealed in her eye,
The drops dry vp, and filth wipe cleane away:
She oft did bath, and oft againe did dry;
The land to sea, and sea to maineland dry,
Or of the clouds to moysten their roots dry;
To dry them selues by Vulcanes flaming light,
But vsd to fish for fooles on the dry shore,
And dry vp all the water, which doth ronne
And a lewd foole her leading thorough dry and wet.
It left, but both did quite drye vp, and blast;
And washeth Winborne meades in season drye.
And skin all withered like a dryed rooke,
As one then in a dreame, whose dryer braine
Till that his army dry-foot through them yod,
Out of his Albion did on dry-foot pas
The whiles his nets were drying on the sand:
His owne faire Dryope now he thinkes not faire,
Dry-shod to passe, she parts the flouds in tway;
And tryumph in their blood, whom she to death did dryue.
Whom she hath vow'd to dub a faire Cucquold.
True is, that I at first was dubbed knight
So he him dubbed, and his Squire did call.
Then th'one her selfe low ducked in the flood,
Flowne at a flush of Ducks, foreby the brooke,
And her due loues deriu'd to that vile witches share.
And poore mens boxes of their due reliefe,
